Temperature: Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.  Since CO2 stayed more or less constant over this time scale, so did temperature.
CO2: The increase in buried carbon release raises one of atmospheric carbon's sources  Carbon sources are now higher than carbon sinks causing an increase in atmospheric CO2.  However, it will take longer than 200 years for a significant change in CO2 to occur.
Volcano: Volcanoes, mountain level, and insolation stay the same throughout this scenario.
Ice: Because temperature remained nearly constant, so did ice level and sea level.
Weathering C Burial: Weathering rate responds to temperature increase.  Since temperature stayed pretty constant over the short 200 year time scale, so did weathering.  Constant weathering will also produce constant carbonate deposition and burial of organic carbon.
Weathering C Release: This scenario shows the effects of a long term increase in buried carbon release due to weathering.  It shows the C release rate increase to medium to show that the effect has started.

Temperature: Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.  Because CO2 rose so did temperature.
CO2: Because carbon sources are now higher than carbon sinks, atmospheric CO2 has increased.  Carbon sources continue to be larger than carbon sinks, which are responding but have not caught up yet.
Ice: Temperature rise causes polar ice to melt lowering the planet's ice level.
Sea: Because ice melted and temperature rose (thermal expansion),  sea level dropped.
Weathering C Burial: Because temperature rose the planet experiences more rainfall, increasing the weathering rate.
CO3 Desposition: Higher weathering rate washes more Ca and C to sea,increasing carbonate deposition rate, increasing the C sinks, although not enough to move system back to equilibrium.
Sediment: Higher weathering increases and amount of sediment produced, causing higher burial of organic life.
Weathering C Release: Buried carbon release continues to rise.

Temperature: Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.  Because CO2 rise so did temperature.
CO2: Because carbon sources are still higher than carbon sinks, atmospheric CO2 continued to increase.  Carbon sources continue to be larger than carbon sinks, which are responding but have not caught up yet.
Ice: Temperature drop causes polar ice melting, lowering the planet's ice level.  At this point, all polar ice has disappeared.
Sea: Because ice melted and temperature rose (thermal expansion),  sea level dropped.
Weathering C Burial: Because temperature rise the planet experiences more rain, increasing the weathering rate.  The weathering rate has now maximized (for the amount of mountains available to be weathered).
CO3 Desposition: Higher weathering rate washes more Ca and C to sea,increasing carbonate deposition rate, increasing the C sinks.  The system is approaching equilibrium.
Sediment: Higher weathering increases and amount of sediment produced, causing higher burial of organic life.
Weathering C Release: Buried carbon release rises to its maximum level.

Temperature: Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.  Because CO2 dropped, so did temperature.
CO2: During this time period, carbon sinks (burial and carbonate deposition) exceeded carbon sources.  Atmospheric carbon began to decline.  They decline until weathering becomes lower, dropping both organic carbon burial and carbonate deposition.  The carbon sources and sinks come into equilibrium.
Ice: Temperature rise causes polar ice to accumulate, raising the planet's ice level.
Sea: Because temperature dropped and ice level rise,  sea level dropped.
Weathering C Burial: Because temperature dropped, the planet experiences less rain, decreasing the weathering rate.
CO3 Desposition: Lower weathering rate washes less Ca and C to sea, decreasing carbonate deposition rate, decreasing the C sinks.  The system now moves to equilibrium.
Sediment: Because sedimentation has dropped, carbon burial drops.  The two sinks unitedly bring carbon sources and sinks back into equilibrium.
Weathering C Release: Buried carbon release stays at its maximum level.
